notes: in early works it was called Oroshor (Rus. «Орошор», hence «Oroshor language»,  «орошорский язык»), which is apparently a mistake; according to Edelman & Yusufbekov, the name «Oroshor» originates in the Kyrgyz pronunciation of «Roshorv»; speakers of Roshorv call themselves рашарвӣҷ (rašarvīǰ) [singular]; according to Kurbanov, in 1976 it had about 110 farms; etymology: according to Dodykhudoev, ro + šorv, where ro ← raw «hill», šorv ← *xarv, which could mean «river» (cf. other hydrotoponyms with this root in Shughnan and Wanj); Edelman is more hesitant to accept the proto-meaning «river» for šorv
